description.p: This weapon can alternatively make a melee attack. 1d6 Slashing + Strength Modifier, reach 5ft.
Mom's Love is the signature weapon of Nalista "Nails" Swiftsteel made from her mother's revolver given to her as she set out to adventure.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls with Mom's Love. If you load no ammunition in the weapon, it produces its own, automatically creating one piece of magic ammunition when you make a ranged attack with it. The ammunition created by the weapon vanishes the instant after it hits or misses a target.
Applying this oil to a suit of metal armor or the joints of a metal construct removes that armor or constructs disadvantage to stealth for 24 hours.

Applying this oil to a suit of metal armor or the joints of a metal construct removes any disadvantage that the armor or construct has to stealth and applies advantage on stealth checks for 8 hours while worn or while the construct is active

This flat iron rod has a button on one end. You can use an action to press the button, which causes the rod to continue to move magically. Until you or another creature uses an action to push the button again, the rod continues to move at a constant speed and direction, even if it is defying gravity. The rod can handle up to 8,000 pounds of opposing force. More force causes the rod to deactivate and fall. A creature can use an action to make a DC 30 Strength check, to deactivate the rod on a success.

This flat iron rod has a button on one end. You can use an action to press the button, which causes the rod to become magically fixed in place. Until you or another creature uses an action to push the button again, the rod doesn't move, even if it is defying gravity. The rod can hold up to 8,000 pounds of weight. More weight causes the rod to deactivate and fall. A creature can use an action to make a DC 30 Strength check, deactivating the rod on a success.

A creature subjected to this poison must make a DC 11 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature begins to turn to stone and is restrained. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is petrified for 24 hours.
This wand has 7 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 or more of its charges to cast the darkness spell from it.
The wand regains 1d6 + 1 expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the wand's last charge, roll a d20. On a 1, the wand crumbles into ashes and is destroyed.

These crystal lenses fit into an enchanted copper eyeglass lens. While wearing them you have darkvision out to 50 ft. and your vision in daylight is reduced to 30 ft. In conditions of clear visibility, you can make out details of creatures and objects 45 ft. away in darkness.
1 over the shoulder bag (sachel equivalent) with 5 lbs of seeds, 1 set of iron farming tools (rake, hoe, and trowel), 1 water canteen, 1 meal kit, one set of common clothes, 2 days of rations.

This rock has 3 charges. Each charge is equivalent to a diamond worth 100gp that can be consumed for a resurrection spell.
The stone regains 1 charge after 10 days.

Bottomless Wine. By itself the Chalice functions as a decanter of endless wine. It will always be at least half full of fine wine and weighs 2 pounds. You can use an action to slosh the wine and speak one of three command words.

ul.li: "Geyser" Produces 30 gallons of fine wine that gushes forth in a tower 30 feet long and 1 foot wide. As a bonus action while holding the chalice, you can aim the geyser at a creature you san see within 30 feet of you. The target must succeed on a DC 13 Strength saving throw or take 1d4 bludgeoning damage and fall prone upon which they must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become drunken for 1 hour (see below).

description.p: Drunkenness.The target gains disadvantage on all Dexterity saving throws and on skill checks related to the dexterity attribute. They further lose 10 movement per round for the duration of the effect and are unable to concentrate on spells for longer than 1 round. However, they gain advantage on Strength checks and saving throws, and on attacks made using their strength modifier.

Potion Concentration.If a potion is mixed with the wine in the chalice its effects will become concentrated by the divine powers of the chalice. If the potion is drunken from the chalice one of the following effects can happen according to the DM's discretion:

ul.li: The duration of the potion is doubled.
The damage of a poison is doubled on a failed save.

description.p: It you drink the potion from the chalice you must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become drunken (see above). The Chalice no longer holds the effect of the potion stored in it once either one creature drinks from the chalice, or one of the command words are used on the chalice. Using a command word resets the chalice so only fine wine is produced by its bottomless wine effect.

If a potion is instead poured out of the Chalice instead of drank, then the chalice will produce 5 vials of the concentrated potions before running out and resetting itself to fine wine. You cannot add concentrated health potions to the chalace.
If you use the Bottomless Wine command words while a potion is in the chalice, the contents will revert to wine before the command activates. Thus wasting the stored potion.

You create a semi-transparent vertical wall made of magical force (AC 25, 10 HP). The wall is a solid object and appears within range. It lasts for the duration or until it takes damage. You can make a straight wall up to 40 feet long, 40 feet high, and 5 feet thick. The wall provides full cover to creatures on either side of it and only creatures you allow can pass through it.

You create a whip made of scorching flame and select one creature within range, with the intention of unbalancing it. The target must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes 5d8 fire damage. If the target is Huge or smaller you can additionally choose to knock it prone or to pull it up to 30 feet closer to your location.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 and you can pull the target an additional 5 feet for each slot level above 3rd.

For the duration, a spectral blade forms on the end of a quarterstaff you touch. While this blade lasts, you use your spellcasting ability instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls of melee attacks using this weapon. The staff retains the damage die and bonusus of the quarterstaff used. The weapon also becomes magical if it isn't already and deals necrotic damage instead of bludgeoning. The spell ends if you cast it again or if you let go of the weapon.

setters.set: a handful of bonemeal and a quarterstaff

description.p: You conjure 2d4 magical darts that last for one hour or until they are used. As an action on your turn, you may expend one of the darts to make a ranged spell attack against a creature you can see within in range. On a successful attack, you deal 2d6 poison damage to the target and force them to make a Constitution saving throw or become poisoned until the end of their next turn.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the you summon and additional 1d4 darts and they last for 1 additional hour for each slot level above 3rd.

You brandish the weapon used in the spell's casting and make a melee attack with it against one creature within 5 feet of you. On a hit, the target suffers the weapon attack's normal effects and then becomes sheathed in cosmic energy until the start of your next turn. If the target willingly moves 5 feet or more before then, the target takes 1d8 radiant damage, and the spell ends.

At Higher Levels. At 5th level, the melee attack deals an extra 1d8 radiant damage to the target on a hit, and the damage the target takes for moving increases to 2d8. Both damage rolls increase by 1d8 at 11th level (2d8 and 3d8) and again at 17th level (3d8 and 4d8).

setters.set: a melee weapon worth at least 1 sp

description.p: Chaotic currents of time rip through a 20-foot-sphere. Each creature in the sphere on the turn when you cast the spell must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 2d8 force damage, and its speed is halved until the end of the next turn. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage and suffers no reduction to its speed.

Until the start of your next turn, any creature outside the sphere attempting to pick up an object in the sphere that isn't being worn or carried must make a successful Strength check against your spell save DC to pick up or move that object.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 1st.

A thick pale mist radiates from you after you take damage from from a melee attack. You are treated as having total cover, but are blinded and deafened until the end of your next turn, or until a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it.

setters.set: 1 reaction, which you take when you are hit by a melee attack that deals damage

description.p: You channel the call of the hunt to yourself or one willing creature you can see within 60 ft, guiding their ranged weapon attack. For the duration, when the target of the spell makes an attack with a ranged weapon, then can use your Spellcasting ability modifier instead of their Dexterity for all attack and damage rolls.
You possess a precious gift coveted not just by mortals but by the gods themselves. As a follower of Kira, you can gain abilities known only by the most loyal.
Kira's Piety. Your devotion improves as your piety score increases. You gain the following traits when you reach the specified piety score.

As an acolyte of Kira, you have proven yourself accomplished at deception. You can call on Kira's blessing and cast chaotic bolt with this trait. You can cast the spell in this way a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.

You can cast suggestion with this trait, requiring no material components. Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell.
You gain advantage on Charisma (Persuasion) and Charisma (Deception) checks.

In addition, when you fail an Charisma check or Charisma saving throw, you can reroll the die, and you must use the new roll. Once you use this reroll, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.
You can increase your Charisma or Wisdom score by 2 and also increase your maximum for that score by 2.

The Orb of Chaos is a perfect bronze sphere covered in archaic, swirling gold inlay script. Around the sphere slowly spins a blocky tarus that changes it's axis of rotation at random. When being used, the inlays of the orb glow with a soft, prismatic light. While equipped this item can serve as a spell casting focus.

Gain Proficiency. While this item is equipped you gain proficiency with any two of the following skills; persuasion, deception, intimidation, or insight. If you're already proficient in that skill, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any check you make with that skill.

Armor of Tempest. You have a +1 to your Armor Class.

â¢ Other creatures can't take a short or long rest within 300 feet of you.

Destroying the Orb. A common rumor among scholars is that the artifact can sense when it is in danger and teleport itself somewhere else in the multiverse. However, if one were to bath the artifact in the blood of Arik, the divine of Law, it would shatter the artifact into three pieces; the orb, the ring, and the key. This renders the orb effectively magicless. To repair the damaged artifact, it requires attuning to all three items and performing the wish spell while inside of a temple of the Kira, the god of chaos. Alternatively, once the pieces are all rejoined, the artifact will naturally repair itself after 1d10x100 years. The pieces will retain their magic so long as chaos still exists in the multiverse.

The key appears as an rectangular curved piece of metal made of bronze with golden inlays. there are indents on the far edges that imply the item is meant to attach to something larger. It is easily tied with leather string to be the amulet of a crude necklace.

The Ring of Chaos is an item of which there is only one on the world. Bronze with spiraling golden inlays and a suspicious gap in on one side of the lattice work giving it the appearance of a torque. This ring somewhat excitable, despite being made of metal and is commonly as a bracelet, armband or necklace depending on the size of the wearer. There is an additional odd chunk that appears to be missing from the outside edge of the ring. Likely where a piece of the item's set locks into place. Sometimes, past holders of the item whisper about hearing the strange delirious voice of the fallen god in their slumber, other say that the rumors are born out of superstition and drunken dreams.
Missing Key. If you attempt to attune to this item while in possession of the Key of Chaos, this item will magically fuse with the key to form a complete ring

Summon Tempest. As an action you can use the ring to summon a tempest horse to be your steed for 24 hours. Once this trait is used, it can be used again for 5 days. If you have a lawful alignment, the horse has a 50% chance to ignore your orders , including a command to return to the ring. If you attempt to mount the Tempest while it is ignoring your orders, she may attempt to attack you

The vines of pharika are made of golden wires, delicately braided and shaped to resemble twisted, leafy vines. When adorned, the armband will alter its size to the arm or forehead of the creature, allowing it to be worn as either an armband or circlet. when combined with Pharika's mortar and pestle, it will bind to the item making a complete artifact.

Follower of Affliction. While attuned to this item you're piety with the goddess Pharika is set to a minimum of 10, allowing you to gain the ability to draw the attention of the goddess of affliction and manifest her power in the following ways:
â¢ Pharika's Devotee. The wearer gains the ability to cast ray of sickness with this trait a number of times equal to their Wisdom modifier.
â¢ Pharika's Aid. The wearer gains proficiency in medicine checks. If you're already proficient in it, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any check you make with it.
Natural Immunities. You are immune to disease and poison.
Bestow Plague. Once per day, the wearer can touch a creature and bestow a contagious disease of the DM's choosing upon a target as an action.
Bestow Remedy. Once per day, the wearer can cra a potion of cure disease using either 1 charge of a healer's kit, 10gp worth of healing herbs, or named herbs the DM designates.

Pharika's Influence. Once attuned to the item, you will forget and be unable to remember the properties of the artifact according to the goddesses will. Should she so choose, she can even prevent you from attuning to cursed items that may interfere with her goals. This extends so far as the item may prevent you from holding telepathic conversations with those that oppose the goddess or seek to undermine her work.

Agent of Pharika. After using either the Bestow Plague or Bestow Remedy abilities of this artifact, there is a high chance that the essence of Pharika causes physical changes to make you appear more like one of her own children. These changes cannot be reversed save for a use of wish or miracle.

Your legs become covered in a scaly hide, and whatever your feet were, are now humanoid but with 4 toes each.
